Steps.Example:
git config --global user.name 'Your Name'
git config --global user.email 'Your Email ID'
Steps.Explanation: To use Git, you first need to configure it on your computer by setting your username and email address. This information will be attached to every commit you make in Git.

No, Git and GitHub are not the same, but they are related concepts 

Git is the core technology that manages version control locally.

GitHub is a platform that makes it easy to store, share, and collaborate on Git repositories over the internet. Other similar platforms include GitLab and Bitbucket.

A Git branch is a separate line of development that allows you to work on different parts of your project without affecting the main codebase.

This is particularly useful for collaboration and managing multiple features, bug fixes, or experiments simultaneously.

Branches help isolate changes, making it easier to review, test, and integrate them back into the main codebase.
To create a new branch, use the `git branch` command followed by the name of the branch you want to create.
To switch to the new branch, use the `git checkout` or `git switch` command followed by the name of the branch.
To create and switch to the new branch in one command, use the `git checkout -b <branch-name>`.

Steps.Example:
git checkout main
git merge feature-login
Steps.Explanation:
Once you're satisfied with the changes you've made on your branch, it's time to merge those changes back into the main codebase.

To do this, switch to the main/master branch and use the `git merge` command.

Make sure you have merged all the changes from the branch you want to delete before running this command.

To delete a branch, use the `git branch` command followed by the `-d` option .

If you need to forcefully delete a branch, use the `-D` flag instead of `-d`.

Git staging is the process of preparing a set of changes to be committed to the Git repository.

It allows you to select only the changes you want to include in the next commit, rather than committing all changes made to the repository.

Steps.Description: Adding changes to the Git Staging Area
Steps.Explanation:
To add changes to the Git Staging Area, use the `git add` command followed by the names of the files you want to add.

This will stage the changes, which means they will be included in the next commit.

To view the changes you have made to the Git repository, use the `git diff` command.

To view only the staged changes, use the `git diff --staged` command. This will display a list of the changes that have been staged and are ready to be committed.

Steps.Description: Removing Changes from the Staging Area
Steps.Explanation:
To remove changes from the Git Staging Area, use the `git reset` command followed by the name of the file you want to remove.

This will remove the changes from the Staging Area, but they will still exist in the working tree.

To commit the changes in the Git Staging Area to the Git repository, use the `git commit` command followed by a commit message.

This will create a new commit in the Git log with the changes you have staged.

GitHub is a web-based platform for version control and collaboration that uses Git.

It provides a centralized repository for projects, making it easier for teams to collaborate on code and track changes.
To start using GitHub, you need to create a GitHub account by visiting the GitHub website and following the sign-up process. You will be asked to provide your username, email address, and password.

1. Log in to your GitHub account.

2. Click the "+" icon in the top-right corner and select "New repository"

3. Provide a name for your repository, a brief description, and choose whether it's public (visible to anyone) or private (visible only to collaborators)

4. Select additional options if needed, such as initializing the repository with a README file

5. Click "Create repository"

Cloning a repository means copying its contents to your local machine.

This allows you to make changes, track them with Git, and push those changes back to the repository.

To clone a GitHub repository to your local machine, use the `git clone` command followed by the URL of the GitHub repository.

 For Example: "git clone https://github.com/firstcontributions/first-contributions.git"

Steps.Description: Making Changes and Pushing to GitHub
Steps.Example:
git add .
git commit -m "message"

git push origin main
Steps.Explanation:
Once you've cloned a repository, you can make changes to the files just like you would with any other Git repository.

After making changes, follow these steps to push your changes to GitHub.

Then use the `git push` command followed by the name of the branch you want to push the changes to. This will upload the changes to the GitHub repository.

gitLessons.LessonTitle: Git to GitHub Workflow using Terminal

Steps.Description: Creating a new Git repository locally
Steps.Explanation: To start using Git for a new project, you need to create a new Git repository. You can do this by navigating to your project's directory in the terminal and running the `git init` command.

Steps.Description: Adding files to the Git repository
Steps.Explanation: To add files to the Git repository, use the `git add` command followed by the file names or `.` to add all files in the directory. Then use the `git commit` command to create a new commit with a message describing the changes you've made.

To create a new GitHub repository, log in to your GitHub account and click on the 'New repository' button. You will be asked to provide a repository name, description, and select the repository's visibility (public or private).

Steps.Description: Adding the GitHub repository as a remote
Steps.Explanation: To link the local Git repository with the GitHub repository, you need to add the GitHub repository as a remote in Git. You can do this using the `git remote add` command followed by the name you want to give the remote (typically `origin`) and the URL of the GitHub repository.

Steps.Description: Pushing the changes to the GitHub repository
Steps.Explanation: To push the changes in the local Git repository to the GitHub repository, use the `git push` command followed by the name of the remote (`origin`) and the branch you want to push the changes to (`master`). The `-u` option sets the remote and branch as the default for future `git push` commands.
